page.syntax: L Validate([SQLConnection as SQL::Connection | SQLConnectionString as C] [UpdateStatistics as L])
page.description: Execute the current statement using the current or passed connection.
page.original:
SQL::Statement::Validate() Syntax Result_Flag as L = .Validate( as SQL::Connection | ConnectionString as C ) Argument Description Result_Flag TRUE (.T.) if the operation was successful; otherwise FALSE (.F.). Optional. A SQL::Connection object created with a DIM statement with a defined .ConnectionString property. ConnectString Optional. A connection string.
Description The .Validate() method prepares the query and validates it, but does not execute it. (In some implementations the query is executed with a limit on rows set to 1). The intent is to force the query through a server side parse and report problems. The method connects to the back-end database using the information in the SQL::Connection::ConnectionString property or in the ConnectString string, then executes the current SQL statement stored in the SQL::Statement.SQLStatement property. Note: Not every database is thorough about validation. Example dim conn as SQL::Connection dim connString as C dim stat as SQL::Statement dim sql_insert as C connString = "{A5API='Access', FileName='c:\program files\a5v7\mdbfiles\alphasports.mdb'}" sql_insert = "insert into customer (firstname, lastname, bill_city, bill_postal_code,bill_state_region) values ('George', 'Jones', 'Arlington', '02000', 'VA')" ? conn.open(connString) = .T. ? stat.parse(sql_insert) = .T. ? stat.validate(conn) = .T.
See Also SQL::Statement Object, About Validation Limitations
